body:
`addCacheIfAbsent` won't fix the problem, it will only move the problem.  When `addCache` fails, it means that there are two applications started at once.  If we switch to `addCacheIfAbsent`, then when one of them shuts down, the second one will start throwing errors when it tries to use the cache, or possibly when it shuts the cache down.  So you'll still get ehcache errors, you'll just get different ones at different times.

The problem here actually isn't Play's global state, it's ehcache's global state, which from my investigations, is impossible to work around, ehcache forces every cache manager to put itself into a global singleton of caches.  Once we've fixed Play's global state problems, this problem will still exist.

Thanks for your explanation, and I definitely agree with not simply moving the problem. What's made this one so frustrating to me is that each time I've seen it it's had a different root cause that's never been anything much to do with ehcache (the last time it was in due to the inclusion of something in `play.modules.enable` that diddled with the lifecycle somehow.)

I think this might be one of those cases where it's merciful to catch and rethrow the original exception with a length explanatory blurb.

issue.title: Provide a more useful error when a named EhCache already exists.

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Since Play manages the ehcache instances this is likely to be caused by starting multiple applications at the same time, and not per se related to ehcache or use of the cache API.

Closes #4717.

body: This is total madness, getting same error on 2.4 with compile time DI. What exactly are we meant to do here? As with @mikesname the root cause somehow shifts around.

I'm reopening this ticket because I think it may be fixable.

At the moment we're using [`CacheManager.create(InputStream)`](http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/net.sf.ehcache/ehcache/2.8.6/net/sf/ehcache/CacheManager.java#CacheManager.create%28java.io.InputStream%29) which creates a singleton and puts the `CacheManager` into a global map using a name read from `InputStream`. You can see the code that calls `CacheManager.create()` in Play's [`CacheManagerProvider`](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/master/framework/src/play-cache/src/main/scala/play/api/cache/Cache.scala#L194-L202).

Instead we should update the `CacheManagerProvider` to:
1. Read the `Configuration` from the `InputStream` ourselves.
2. Call `Configuration.setName()` to give it a random name so it won't conflict in the global map.
3. Call [`CacheManager.newInstance(Configuration, ...)`](http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/net.sf.ehcache/ehcache/2.8.6/net/sf/ehcache/CacheManager.java#CacheManager.newInstance%28java.io.InputStream%29) to create a non-singleton `CacheManager`.

At least I think that would work. Can someone investigate?

hi @nowxue are you able to paste up some code of how you bound your CustomCacheManagerProvider using DI? I am having trouble understanding the documentation.

Thanks

Sure, you have to create a custom loader and register it in application.conf:

```
import play.api.ApplicationLoader
import play.api.inject._
import play.api.inject.guice._
import net.sf.ehcache.CacheManager

class CustomApplicationLoader extends GuiceApplicationLoader() {
  override def builder(context: ApplicationLoader.Context): GuiceApplicationBuilder = {
    initialBuilder
      .in(context.environment)
      .loadConfig(context.initialConfiguration)
      .overrides(overrides(context): _*)
      //We just override default cache provider with custom one
      .overrides(bind[CacheManager].toProvider[CustomCacheManagerProvider])
  }
}
```

And in application.conf: `play.application.loader = "core.CustomApplicationLoader"`
Thanks @nowxue that works for me too

I'm seeing this issue with my students in Play training, using Play 2.5.0. 

Was this ever fixed? the bug shows as closed...
I'm also curius why this issue is fixed. I see this problem in test `WithBrowser` when I switch to Play 2.5.3 this week.
I have the same problem if try to run tests suites with PlaySpecs but adding CustomCacheManagerProvider fixed it
do anyone knows if this is  fixed in play 2.6 ?
Nope - still seeing this error in 2019.  :/.
